justification: The article cites the study "Diminished size-weight illusion in anorexia nervosa: evidence for visuo-proprioceptive integration deficit," indicating that performance on the size-weight illusion is used as evidence (i.e., a measure) of visuo-proprioceptive integration.

It notes that "AN patients have a higher sensitivity to the rubber hand illusion," implying that the rubber hand illusion is employed to gauge the construct of body ownership or multisensory integration processes.

The text states that "Using semi-structured interview techniques, researchers have discovered significant between-patient differences in belief characteristics such as conviction and incorrigibility," showing that these interviews function as the measurement tool for those belief attributes.
